Editors Of "Hullabaloo"
Request All Payments
By March 2
In order to fulfill the editorial
plans for the 1934 Hullabaloo,
the editors request that the following resolutions be carried out
by all concerned:
1. SENIORS—Pay class dues by
March 2. Payable at Student Shop or Hullabaloo
office.
2. FRATERNITIES AND CLUBS—
Pay bills by March 2: Payable at ,Hullabaloo office,
12.30 to 1. If paying by
check, make payable to 1934
Hullabaloo.
3. STUDENT BODY—Sign up for
your Hullabaloo. Subscription at Post Office and Hullabaloo office.
Payment of bills by fraternities and clubs by March 2 will
enable all remaining portraits except those of seniors to be taken
without deposit. According to
the editors, this will greatly simplify the situation.

Tuesday, February 27, 1934.

What's He Preparing For?
It has been, unfortunately, an all-tob-common
criticism of the college education that it seldom prepares the student for the particular type of work in
which he engages after graduation. We are shown
the B.S.-in-chemistry at work on the local newspaper;
the engineering grad floor-walking in a department
store; or the economics student selling silk stockings
from door to door. And such anomalies are distorted
into scathing indictments of the educational system.
But such a reaction to the tragically-humorous
situation of the misplaced college student is not an
intelligent one. Even after the condition is modified
by realizing that the economic maladjustment of our
present time is largely responsible for the graduates'
plight, the universities still may be cleared of the
charge of having proven themselves fruitless. The
justification comes in recognizing the use to which
most students intend to put their educations.
Let's set aside for the moment the ideal of a
university education—that the cause of truth may be
propagated and the world be bettered for having
more intelligent citizens. It's a nice platitude and is
adhered to with varying degrees of tenacity. But
it is yet undeniable that most students come to college
to fit themselves to achieve economic independence.
The idealistic side is merely incidental. And a college education derived in the proper manner will certainly contribute tremendously to the ability, to become
independent.
Whether the preparation for a career be specific
or not the essential point of learning is the acquirement of a mental capacity—which, in turn, is a combination of alertness and adaptability. The actual
technique of an individual science is unimportant provided the student grasp the rational processes underlying it. If college teaches young men to cope with
problems and to attack difficulties of a varied nature
with some degree of success the question of whether
or not they find an opening in their specialized field
will have little effect upon their ability to advance
themselves. A well-trained mind can make itself
adept in almost any kind of intellectual exercise.

Football Has Not Blinded Our Eyes
(Editor's note: The following article appeared as
an editorial in the Southern California "Daily Trojan." It was written in reply to the annual report of
the Carnegie foundation for the advancement of
teaching, in which Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the foundation, scored commercialism in modern college football and directed attacks against Notre
Dame and Southern California far their alleged dedi-

cation of profit-motives in making a three-year contract for games.)
Southern , California students this morning may
wonder why the Daily Trojan prints the charges
against the university by Henry S. Pritchett,. of New
York, president emeritus of the Carnegie foundation
for the advancement of teaching, who accuses S. C. of
undue emphasis on football.
We believe that Dr. Pritchett has heard but one
side of the story concerning the University of Southern California. If it is true that Trojan Football teams
have carried the name of the university throughout
the United States, and it is unfortunate in this regard
that many people hear of the university in no other
connection than football. They hear of packed stadiums, they hear the games over the radio on Saturday
afternoon, they hear the stirring Trojan marching
songs all the year round and they think of the university in no other terms.
This we regret deeply. We know, and we wish
others knew, the other side of S. C. How many of
those people who shout the word "Trojan" on Saturday afternoon know that behind Trojan stands the
foremost school of rithilosophy in the United States,
that the speech school is rated foremost in the West,
that valuable research is being carried on by the School
of Medicine, that the student newspaper is one of the
most liberal in the country, and that S. C. students
study under a most enlightened faculty?
These are things that people forget, yet they, not
football, make up the university. Because we have
been fortunate in having a team which has won a large
percentage of its games during the past three years we
hear the "cry that we are a football school, when
this is not necessarily the case. Other schools do the
very same things that Dr. Pritchett considers so bad
in Southern California and Notre Dame, but they
receive no unfavorable mention.
We feel that Dr. Pritchett should not worry
about the intellectual attainments of the university
simply because the football team has had better than
average success. We wish him to know that we love
and cherish the ideal of a university here as much as
in the cultural centers of Europe, that we are mindful
of the purpose of an educational institution, and
that we do not intend that we should lose sight of the
devotion and purpose of the fathers who created this
university in southern California.

In The News
SABERS VERSUS
THE PIGSKIN

ALTHOUGH the expectations
of all were verified when the annual
report of the Carnegie Foundation
was issued last Sunday, containing
the annual slap at professionalism in
college football, the report did contain a more important and much
more startling revelation. This was
that German student duels are much
safer than college football.
Though the report, written by Dr.
Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation
for the Advancement of Teaching,
will in all probability not be taken
very seriously by the students at
American colleges, its contents are
of unusual interest. In explaining
his assertion that the duels engaged
in by German students are safer
than football, Dr. Pritchett declared
that in the duels "A fatal encounter
is practically unknown, and a serious
wound so rare as to be negligible."
But this assertion is to be
strongly questioned, even in view
of the fact that dueling is not very
likely to be substituted for football
at the Hopkins and other universities of the United States. For in
the duels serious wounds are not
rare at all. Unlike the American
sport of football, the duels of the
Heidelberg youths are affairs of
honor. Naturally, when a passionate young man has been insulted and
he challenges another man to a duel
for satisfaction, he is out to punish
the man with as good a saber slash
as possible. The result is to be
seen when the surgeons fix up the
face of the loser, which may be laid
open from ear to ear; and, if the
wound is a serious one, the man will
carry a hideous scar on his face for
the rest of his life. The Germans
themselves recognized the evils of
student dueling, and it was outlawed in Germany until Herr Hitler came to the seat of power and
removed the ban.

HER MAJESTY,
QUEEN ELIZABETH

THE RECENT sad death of
King Albert I of Belgium has
brought up stories of many things
besides the perils of mountain climbing. One of these concerns the visit
some time ago of the King and
Queen to the United States, and
Dr. Adolph Meyer, the organizer
and director of the Henry Phipps
Psychiatric clinic at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
During the visit of the royal pair
to these shores, Queen Elizabeth
was being conducted through the
Johns Hopkins Hospital by Dr. William S. Thayer. On the way around,
so the story goes, Dr. Thayer took
the Queen through the Phipps Clinic, where, in the course of the tour,
they encountered Dr. Meyer. Dr.
Thayer stopped Dr. Meyer to present him to the Queen of Belgium.
"Your Majesty," he said, with a
courtly bow, "this is Dr. Meyer."
Dr. Meyer glanced at Queen
Elizabeth with a keen psychiatrical
eye. Addressing Dr. Thayer, he
asked: "How long has she had this
idea ?"

Leaky Ceiling Is
Target In N. Y. U.
Hopkins Debate
Johns Hopkins And N. Y. U.
Teams Argue President's
Emergency Powers
A leak in the roof became a storm
center of debate last Thursday
night at the Community Center at
Staten Island, New York, as teams
from the Johns Hopkins and New
York Universities wrestled with
the problem of whether or not to
make the President's emergency
powers permanent.
Frederic Bang, upholding the
negative for Hopkins, was making
the point that many things must be
allowed to await the advent of better times during a depression . . .
and so many things are delayed. The
old suit of clothes is made to do one
more season, and if it is not too bad;
ven a leak in the roof is tolerated
till better times make its repair
possible.
Cocking his head upward to follow the eyes of the 200-odd Center
members present, Bang was nonplussed to see the plaster of a considerable ceiling area discolored and
wet. He soon regained his poise
and continued the argument, however.
"If you have a leak in the roof,"
said John Keller, of the N. Y. U.
team and captain of the university's
debating squad of fifty, "and you
have," he continued cooly, as the
,
,
evening s first drop of water landed
with a very noticeable spat on a
sheet of loose paper,"you must have
a man fix it, and not count on its
fixing itself."
J. G. Lyman of the Hopkins,
urging that these Presidential emergency powers should be removed as
soon as possible, stressed the point
that while they may be used to better the country by a man like
Roosevelt, "known as one of the
most determined men ever to hold
office, "what can we hope for under
a President of less worthy caliber?
The N. Y. U. team, composed of
Keller and Mortimer Grieff, pointed
out that the recent laissez-faire type
of democratic government, with its
lack of industrial and governmental
planning, could never hope to rid
ourt eceonomic life of the boomtime—and depression cycle, nor
correct the present condition, wherein ten per cent of the population
controls ninety per cent of the country's wealth.
One of the members of the audience asked the question at the end
of the debate, "are the President's
powers to be permanent ?" and acted
quite abashed when Mr. Max Levey,
prominent New York attorney and
honorary president of the Community Center, who presided at the debate, replied, "That is the subject
of the debate."

International
Club To Reorganize At
Meeting Thursday
Efforts will be made to complete
the reorganization of the International Relations Club at the meeting to be held this Thursday, it was
announced yesterday by Stuart B.
LeCompte, Jr., secretary. The general tendency will be to make the
club more of an undergraduate
group.
Commenting on Thursday's meeting, LeCompte said:
"Every undergraduate, each lower classman is urged to meet with
the International Relations Club on
Thursday, March 1st at 1 o'clock
in Gilman 305.

—to bring facts and information to
its members. But the club takes no
stand on the issues which it investigates; its programs present merely
information on international questions, but does this by stimulating
discussion, by hearing the opinions
of prominent speakers, and by encouraging student members to work
up special topics for the benefit of
the others.
Library Available

"A library of selected recent
books on international, subjects is
open to the use of members through
the generosity of the Carnegie
Foundation for International Peace.
"This Thursday, March 1st, the
club program will be stated more
fully by club officers and the present
membership.

Helpful To Undergrads

"This student group can be intensely interesting and helpful to
the under graduate body. Its aim is
to keep lively touch with the movements and attitudes among nations

Dr. Louis Cazamian
To Lecture March 6
Dr. Louis Cazamian, professor of
Modern English Literature and
Civilization in the Faculty of Letters at the University of Paris, will
speak at the annual public lecture
of the Tudor and Stuart Club in
Levering Hall on Tuesday, March
6, at 5 p. m. The subject of his address will be "The Humor of Falstaff."
The Tudor and Stuart Club was
formed by Sir William and Lady
Osler as a memorial to their son,
Edward Revere Osler. The club
consists of students who are interested in the study of English literature.

Tuesday, February 27, 1934.

What's He Preparing For?
It has been, unfortunately, an all-tob-common
criticism of the college education that it seldom prepares the student for the particular type of work in
which he engages after graduation. We are shown
the B.S.-in-chemistry at work on the local newspaper;
the engineering grad floor-walking in a department
store; or the economics student selling silk stockings
from door to door. And such anomalies are distorted
into scathing indictments of the educational system.
But such a reaction to the tragically-humorous
situation of the misplaced college student is not an
intelligent one. Even after the condition is modified
by realizing that the economic maladjustment of our
present time is largely responsible for the graduates'
plight, the universities still may be cleared of the
charge of having proven themselves fruitless. The
justification comes in recognizing the use to which
most students intend to put their educations.
Let's set aside for the moment the ideal of a
university education—that the cause of truth may be
propagated and the world be bettered for having
more intelligent citizens. It's a nice platitude and is
adhered to with varying degrees of tenacity. But
it is yet undeniable that most students come to college
to fit themselves to achieve economic independence.
The idealistic side is merely incidental. And a college education derived in the proper manner will certainly contribute tremendously to the ability, to become
independent.
Whether the preparation for a career be specific
or not the essential point of learning is the acquirement of a mental capacity—which, in turn, is a combination of alertness and adaptability. The actual
technique of an individual science is unimportant provided the student grasp the rational processes underlying it. If college teaches young men to cope with
problems and to attack difficulties of a varied nature
with some degree of success the question of whether
or not they find an opening in their specialized field
will have little effect upon their ability to advance
themselves. A well-trained mind can make itself
adept in almost any kind of intellectual exercise.

Football Has Not Blinded Our Eyes
(Editor's note: The following article appeared as
an editorial in the Southern California "Daily Trojan." It was written in reply to the annual report of
the Carnegie foundation for the advancement of
teaching, in which Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the foundation, scored commercialism in modern college football and directed attacks against Notre
Dame and Southern California far their alleged dedi-

cation of profit-motives in making a three-year contract for games.)
Southern , California students this morning may
wonder why the Daily Trojan prints the charges
against the university by Henry S. Pritchett,. of New
York, president emeritus of the Carnegie foundation
for the advancement of teaching, who accuses S. C. of
undue emphasis on football.
We believe that Dr. Pritchett has heard but one
side of the story concerning the University of Southern California. If it is true that Trojan Football teams
have carried the name of the university throughout
the United States, and it is unfortunate in this regard
that many people hear of the university in no other
connection than football. They hear of packed stadiums, they hear the games over the radio on Saturday
afternoon, they hear the stirring Trojan marching
songs all the year round and they think of the university in no other terms.
This we regret deeply. We know, and we wish
others knew, the other side of S. C. How many of
those people who shout the word "Trojan" on Saturday afternoon know that behind Trojan stands the
foremost school of rithilosophy in the United States,
that the speech school is rated foremost in the West,
that valuable research is being carried on by the School
of Medicine, that the student newspaper is one of the
most liberal in the country, and that S. C. students
study under a most enlightened faculty?
These are things that people forget, yet they, not
football, make up the university. Because we have
been fortunate in having a team which has won a large
percentage of its games during the past three years we
hear the "cry that we are a football school, when
this is not necessarily the case. Other schools do the
very same things that Dr. Pritchett considers so bad
in Southern California and Notre Dame, but they
receive no unfavorable mention.
We feel that Dr. Pritchett should not worry
about the intellectual attainments of the university
simply because the football team has had better than
average success. We wish him to know that we love
and cherish the ideal of a university here as much as
in the cultural centers of Europe, that we are mindful
of the purpose of an educational institution, and
that we do not intend that we should lose sight of the
devotion and purpose of the fathers who created this
university in southern California.

In The News
SABERS VERSUS
THE PIGSKIN

ALTHOUGH the expectations
of all were verified when the annual
report of the Carnegie Foundation
was issued last Sunday, containing
the annual slap at professionalism in
college football, the report did contain a more important and much
more startling revelation. This was
that German student duels are much
safer than college football.
Though the report, written by Dr.
Henry S. Pritchett, president emeritus of the Carnegie Foundation
for the Advancement of Teaching,
will in all probability not be taken
very seriously by the students at
American colleges, its contents are
of unusual interest. In explaining
his assertion that the duels engaged
in by German students are safer
than football, Dr. Pritchett declared
that in the duels "A fatal encounter
is practically unknown, and a serious
wound so rare as to be negligible."
But this assertion is to be
strongly questioned, even in view
of the fact that dueling is not very
likely to be substituted for football
at the Hopkins and other universities of the United States. For in
the duels serious wounds are not
rare at all. Unlike the American
sport of football, the duels of the
Heidelberg youths are affairs of
honor. Naturally, when a passionate young man has been insulted and
he challenges another man to a duel
for satisfaction, he is out to punish
the man with as good a saber slash
as possible. The result is to be
seen when the surgeons fix up the
face of the loser, which may be laid
open from ear to ear; and, if the
wound is a serious one, the man will
carry a hideous scar on his face for
the rest of his life. The Germans
themselves recognized the evils of
student dueling, and it was outlawed in Germany until Herr Hitler came to the seat of power and
removed the ban.

HER MAJESTY,
QUEEN ELIZABETH

THE RECENT sad death of
King Albert I of Belgium has
brought up stories of many things
besides the perils of mountain climbing. One of these concerns the visit
some time ago of the King and
Queen to the United States, and
Dr. Adolph Meyer, the organizer
and director of the Henry Phipps
Psychiatric clinic at the Johns Hopkins Hospital.
During the visit of the royal pair
to these shores, Queen Elizabeth
was being conducted through the
Johns Hopkins Hospital by Dr. William S. Thayer. On the way around,
so the story goes, Dr. Thayer took
the Queen through the Phipps Clinic, where, in the course of the tour,
they encountered Dr. Meyer. Dr.
Thayer stopped Dr. Meyer to present him to the Queen of Belgium.
"Your Majesty," he said, with a
courtly bow, "this is Dr. Meyer."
Dr. Meyer glanced at Queen
Elizabeth with a keen psychiatrical
eye. Addressing Dr. Thayer, he
asked: "How long has she had this
idea ?"

It was then extremely difficult to
choose between Carney of Loyola
and Lynch of Mount St. Mary's,
both of whom were important factors in their teams' play. These two
Performers polled the same number
of votes, and since there was an
evident lack of meritorious forwards, it was possible to include
both of these basketeers on the first
team by shifting Kelly to forward.
This decision cannot be considered
too radical for Kelly showed himself equally adept at any position on
the court.

Teaming up with Kelly at forward is Ryscavage of Western
Maryland. A seasoned basketball
player, who is at his best when the
going is toughest, he was the steadying influence on the Terror quintet.
His particular forte was in covering
the tap from Sadausky at center,
which enabled his team to obtain
possession of the majority of the
jumps.

points per game, in addition to
scooping up rebounds at both ends

Announcement of the 1934
schedule of the Hopkins tennis team
will be made the latter part of this
week. According to present plans,
the annual northern trip will include such teams as Ya16, Army,and
Princeton.

the near future.

Leaky Ceiling Is
Target In N. Y. U.
Hopkins Debate
Johns Hopkins And N. Y. U.
Teams Argue President's
Emergency Powers
A leak in the roof became a storm
center of debate last Thursday
night at the Community Center at
Staten Island, New York, as teams
from the Johns Hopkins and New
York Universities wrestled with
the problem of whether or not to
make the President's emergency
powers permanent.
Frederic Bang, upholding the
negative for Hopkins, was making
the point that many things must be
allowed to await the advent of better times during a depression . . .
and so many things are delayed. The
old suit of clothes is made to do one
more season, and if it is not too bad;
ven a leak in the roof is tolerated
till better times make its repair
possible.
Cocking his head upward to follow the eyes of the 200-odd Center
members present, Bang was nonplussed to see the plaster of a considerable ceiling area discolored and
wet. He soon regained his poise
and continued the argument, however.
"If you have a leak in the roof,"
said John Keller, of the N. Y. U.
team and captain of the university's
debating squad of fifty, "and you
have," he continued cooly, as the
,
,
evening s first drop of water landed
with a very noticeable spat on a
sheet of loose paper,"you must have
a man fix it, and not count on its
fixing itself."
J. G. Lyman of the Hopkins,
urging that these Presidential emergency powers should be removed as
soon as possible, stressed the point
that while they may be used to better the country by a man like
Roosevelt, "known as one of the
most determined men ever to hold
office, "what can we hope for under
a President of less worthy caliber?
The N. Y. U. team, composed of
Keller and Mortimer Grieff, pointed
out that the recent laissez-faire type
of democratic government, with its
lack of industrial and governmental
planning, could never hope to rid
ourt eceonomic life of the boomtime—and depression cycle, nor
correct the present condition, wherein ten per cent of the population
controls ninety per cent of the country's wealth.
One of the members of the audience asked the question at the end
of the debate, "are the President's
powers to be permanent ?" and acted
quite abashed when Mr. Max Levey,
prominent New York attorney and
honorary president of the Community Center, who presided at the debate, replied, "That is the subject
of the debate."

ONLY THE
CENTER LEAVES FOR

Relations
International
Club To Reorganize At
Meeting Thursday
Efforts will be made to complete
the reorganization of the International Relations Club at the meeting to be held this Thursday, it was
announced yesterday by Stuart B.
LeCompte, Jr., secretary. The general tendency will be to make the
club more of an undergraduate
group.
Commenting on Thursday's meeting, LeCompte said:
"Every undergraduate, each lower classman is urged to meet with
the International Relations Club on
Thursday, March 1st at 1 o'clock
in Gilman 305.

—to bring facts and information to
its members. But the club takes no
stand on the issues which it investigates; its programs present merely
information on international questions, but does this by stimulating
discussion, by hearing the opinions
of prominent speakers, and by encouraging student members to work
up special topics for the benefit of
the others.
Library Available

"A library of selected recent
books on international, subjects is
open to the use of members through
the generosity of the Carnegie
Foundation for International Peace.
"This Thursday, March 1st, the
club program will be stated more
fully by club officers and the present
membership.

Helpful To Undergrads

"This student group can be intensely interesting and helpful to
the under graduate body. Its aim is
to keep lively touch with the movements and attitudes among nations

Dr. Louis Cazamian
To Lecture March 6
Dr. Louis Cazamian, professor of
Modern English Literature and
Civilization in the Faculty of Letters at the University of Paris, will
speak at the annual public lecture
of the Tudor and Stuart Club in
Levering Hall on Tuesday, March
6, at 5 p. m. The subject of his address will be "The Humor of Falstaff."
The Tudor and Stuart Club was
formed by Sir William and Lady
Osler as a memorial to their son,
Edward Revere Osler. The club
consists of students who are interested in the study of English literature.

Chessmen Needed
As a result of the recent scheduling of several matches with nearby
colleges, the Chess Club has issued a
call for new candidates.
All students who are interested ii:
chess are requested to communicate
with Albert M. Potts, P. 0. Box
647.
